description: From Middle English thistel, from Old English þistel, from Proto-West Germanic *þistil, from Proto-Germanic *þistilaz. *þīh- from *teyg-, which is a variant of Proto-Indo-European *(s)teyg- (“to prick”); from this same Proto-Indo-European root comes English stick.
Cognates include Scots thrissel, German Distel, Dutch distel and Icelandic þistill.

entries.meaning: Any of several perennial composite plants, especially of genera Cirsium, Carduus, Cynara, or Onopordum, having prickly leaves and showy flower heads with prickly bracts.
examples: Thorns also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee; and thou shalt eat the herb of the field [...].

entries.meaning: This plant seen as the national emblem of Scotland.
(heraldry) This plant used as a charge.
The Order of the Thistle, or membership thereof.
examples: Here's a passage which will please you: ‘It is said that when rich he twice refused the thistle.’
